description: From Middle English debaten, from Old French debatre (“to fight, contend, debate, also literally to beat down”), from Romanic desbattere, from Latin dis- (“apart, in different directions”) + battuere (“to beat, to fence”).

entries.meaning: An argument, or discussion, usually in an ordered or formal setting, often with more than two people, generally ending with a vote or other decision.
examples: After a four-hour debate, the committee voted to table the motion.

entries.meaning: An informal and spirited but generally civil discussion of opposing views.
examples: The debate over the age of the universe is thousands of years old.
There was a bit of a debate over who should pay for the damaged fence.
There has been considerable debate concerning exactly how to format these articles.

entries.meaning: (frequently in the French form débat) A type of literary composition, taking the form of a discussion or disputation, commonly found in the vernacular medieval poetry of many European countries, as well as in medieval Latin.

verbs.description: debate (third-person singular simple present debates, present participle debating, simple past and past participle debated)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To participate in a debate; to dispute, argue, especially in a public arena. [from 14th c.]
examples: He presents that great soul debating upon the subject of life and death with his intimate friends.
To change your day of youth to sullied night

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive) To engage in combat for; to strive for.
(transitive) To consider (to oneself), to think over, to attempt to decide
examples: He was debating where he'd spend his holiday.
